captions.text:
From towns on the valley floor, a train takes
tourists and adventurers alike to the region's

ultimate perch — the Jungfraujoch. This
breathtaking station sits like a fairy castle

at 11,000 feet, between two of the region's
highest peaks. The weather is usually better

in the early morning — 
we're on the first train.

Towering high above are the Jungfrau, Mönch,
and Eiger peaks — named for the legend of

the young maiden (Jungfrau) being protected by the
monk (or Mönch) from the mean ogre (or Eiger).

Continuing on, we change trains at 
Kleine Scheidegg,

a rail junction at the base of these peaks. 
It has shops, rustic beds, and

hearty food for hikers. This is the jumping-off
point for rock climbers attempting to scale

the foreboding north face 
of the Eiger.

This train incredibly 
tunnels through the

inside of the Eiger on its slow yet exhilarating
climb to the literal high point of any trip

to the Swiss Alps — the Jungfraujoch. Swiss
engineers dug this tunnel and built this railway

over 100 years ago. Why? Because they could...and
for the viewing pleasure of those 19th-century
Romantic Age visitors. Halfway up the Eiger, the train stops at panorama windows.

Rock climbers can exit here into
an unforgiving world of ice and air.

After another short tunnel ride, you emerge
at 11,000 feet — the top of Europe. Spectacular

views of majestic peaks stretch as far as
you can see. Cradled among these giants, you

understand the timeless allure of 
the Swiss Alps.

An elevator carries you to the highest viewing
point. From there, you can see Aletsch Glacier

— Europe's longest — stretching 11 miles
south towards Italy. The air is thin...people

are in giddy moods. It's cold even on a sunny day. 
While the Jungfraujoch station calls

itself the "Top of Europe," it's possible to
venture even higher.

title: Switzerland's Jungfrau Region: The Top of Europe
